PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIAN, JAPANESE AND SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS: Sony (6758 JT) is to repurchase as much as JPY 200bln in shares, Sumitomo Realty & Development (8830 JT) Q4 net JPY 130.8bln vs. Prev. JPY 199.7bln Y/Y
content:
AUSTRALIA

Fortescue Metals (FMG AT) - Western Australia Premier McGowan said the Co. will not receive the same royalty relief as China’s CITIC. (AFR)

ImpediMed (IPD AT) - Co.’s PREVENT trial showed positive results for breast cancer survivors which demonstrated 95% reduction in lymphedema progression. (Newswires)

Sundance Energy (SEA AT) - Co. Q1 net loss AUD 31.4mln vs. Prev. loss AUD 15.6mln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Virgin Australia (VAH AT) - Co. sees FY19 underlying earnings to be at least AUD 100mln lower Y/Y, although sees revenue higher by 6% Y/Y. (Newswires)

Basic Materials and Energy - Iron ore prices rose 2.3% and WTI crude futures gained around 2% to above USD 63.00/bbl. (Newswires)

Other news - RBA watcher McCrann firmly believes the RBA will cut the cash rate at the June meeting and suggested it is locked in “no ifs, no buts and no probabilities”. (Herald Sun)

 

JAPAN

Sony (6758 JT) - Co. is to repurchase as much as JPY 200bln in shares or 4.8% of total. (Newswires)

Sumitomo Realty & Development (8830 JT) - Co. Q4 net JPY 130.8bln vs. Prev. JPY 199.7bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Takeda Pharmaceutical (4502 JT) - Co. expects binding bids for Latin American assets by end of May. (Newswires)

Financials - Moody’s changed outlook on Japan’s banking system to negative from stable. (Newswires)

Other News - Japan’s ruling LDP said the sales tax is to be raised unless a crisis occurs. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Hyundai Heavy (009540 KS) - Co. workers conducted a partial strike yesterday in protest of plans to split the Co. as part of a merger Daewoo Shipbuilding & Marine, while Co. unit received a USD 100bln deal for industrial boilers. (Yonhap)

Kakao Corp (035720 KS) - Affinity is to sell shares in Co. at KRW 127.0k/Shr vs. last close KRW 133.5K/Shr. (Newswires)

Samsung Heavy Industries (010140 KS) - Co. has been ordered to pay EnscoRowan USD 180mln by an arbitration tribunal. (Newswires)

ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASES CALENDAR NOW AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION: Highlights include New Zealand PPI and Singapore Non-Oil Exports

content:
ASIA-PAC

China cancelled US pork import order as trade war drags on. (CNBC)

RBA watcher McCrann firmly believes the RBA will cut the cash rate at the June meeting and suggested it is locked in “no ifs, no buts and no probabilities”. (Herald Sun)

 

UK/EU

UK PM May will meet with 1922 Committee Chairman Brady after the vote for her Withdrawal Agreement Bill to set out a timetable for her departure and the election of a new Tory leader. In related news, PM May is expected to resign whether or not the Withdrawal Agreement Bill passes in June and a leadership election this summer is now a dead certain, according to ITV's Paul Brand citing 1922 Committee Chairman Brady. (Newswires/Twitter)

UK opposition Labour leader Corbyn is reportedly "inching" closer to getting behind a new Brexit referendum. (ITV) 

 

COMMODITIES

Iraq Oil Minister said oil markets are stable and there is no acute volatility, while he added the upcoming JMMC meeting will assess commitment of OPEC/OPEC+ to production cuts and suggested it is too early to predict OPEC decision. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump reportedly told Acting Defense Secretary Shanahan in the Situation Room that he does not want to go to war with Iran. (NYT) 

 

US

US Commerce Secretary Ross said talks are ongoing with Mexico and Canada on metals tariffs, while he also commented that President Trump will decide if auto tariffs talks will continue beyond May and said the US made good progress on China trade talks but China decided to backtrack. (Newswires)

Fed’s Brainard (Voter, Dove) said the employment/inflation relationship has "broken down" and that weak inflation poses risks that households and businesses could set expectations in a way that makes it harder for the Fed to reach its inflation goal. Brainard also commented that low unemployment is helping the workers at the margin of the labour market, but low interest rates pose risks to financial markets. (Newswires)

Fed's Kashkari (Non-Voter, Dove) said wages are rising but not so fast to believe inflation will surge and rhetorically questioned why put the brakes on growth by raising rates but added that the Fed can always hike rates if wages start to rise too quickly. Furthermore, Kashkari said he would not prefer cutting rates as insurance and does not think it would do much for inflation expectations, while he thinks tariffs could boost inflation temporarily. (Newswires)

  • US Philly Fed Business Index (May) 16.6 vs. Exp. 9.0 (Prev. 8.5). (Newswires)
  • US Building Permits Number (Apr) 1.296M vs. Exp. 1.29M (Prev. 1.288M)
  • US Housing Starts Number (Apr) 1.235M vs. Exp. 1.205M (Prev. 1.139M, Rev. 1.168M)

 

MARKET RECAP

The Trump administration’s decision to ban US telecommunications companies from using foreign equipment that would pose a threat to national security weighed heavily on a number of tech names with close ties to Chinese technology companies such as Huawei. Qualcom (QCOM), Xilinx (XLNX), Skyworks Solutions (SWKS), Qorvo (QRVO), Micron Technologies (MU), Analog Devices (ADI) and IPG Photonics Corp (IPGP) all finished firmly in the red. Cisco Systems (CSCO), however, shrugged off US/China trade related concerns, moving higher premarket after posting strong earnings; the chipmaker beating expectations on both top and bottom lines whilst revising Q4 guidance higher, a revision which the co said does take into account the impact of tariffs. Walmart (WMT) also moved higher after posting strong earnings. These strong earnings, in addition to strong housing data, helped propel Wall Street to a third consecutive day of gains, in which large tech names were some of the key beneficiaries. Microsoft (MSFT), Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL) and PayPal (PYPL) all moved higher. Amazon (AMZN) also moved higher, with the share price finding additional support form news the tech giant would introduce a new model of its Fire device aimed at children. Banking names including, JP Morgan Chase (JPM) and Citigroup (C), where unfazed after the EU issued fines to multiple firms in relation to involvement in spot foreign exchange cartels. Tesla (TSLA) shares were under pressure after the electric automaker announced it will update its battery software following the spontaneous combustion of another of its Model S vehicles, whilst also facing news that Asset Manager T. Rowe Price had been selling its shares. Healthcare, Pharma and Biotech names also participated in the wider rally, with the exception of Nektar Therapeutics (NKTR), who sunk on a reduction in Sabby Managements 13-F filing. Boeing (BA) caught a bid later in the session on the back of it announcing it had completed a 737 MAX software update. S&P 500 0.9% AT 2876, NASDAQ-100 1% AT 7580, DOW JONES 0.8% AT 25863.

At settlement, the curve had bear-flattened, though in early trade, there was a bid in the complex after news that Trump was going to take action on Huawei. The tough talk out of China’s MOFCOM also gave support to the complex in the European morning. However, after the European cash open, Treasury yields began to rise, and were booted higher further after a decent slate of US data. After that data, the drift has generally been horizontal. US T-note futures settled 8 ticks lower at 124-13+.

subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 16 MAY 2019: Equities continue flip-flop, finish higher; USD higher on data beats
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

US MARKET WRAP 16 MAY 2019: Equities continue flip-flop, finish higher; USD higher on data beats

 

* SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Dollar up, Treasuries down, Crude up.

* REAR VIEW: US bans certain foreign tech; delay in US auto tariffs not certain; Fed’s Brainard & Kashkari; UK PM May to lay out plan step down; strong US data; Trump opposed to war in Iran.

* COMING UP: Data: EZ CPI (Final); US University of Michigan Sentiment. Speakers: Fed's Clarida & Williams Speaking; BoJ's Kuroda & ECB's de Guindos

* FRIDAY’S EARNINGS: Deere & Co, EasyJet

 

* TRADE WARS: After market on Wednesday, the Trump Administration announced a national emergency to protect US computer networks. The measures did not name a company, but seem to be aimed at China's Huawei (and ZTE), banning it from buying key US tech without approval, and effectively banning its equipment from US telecom networks. China's foreign ministry said that Beijing will take necessary measures to safeguard its rights and interests, and also suggested that moves against Huawei could overshadow the ongoing trade talks. China's commerce ministry stated that the nation firmly opposes bullying by the US, adding that China will have to take countermeasures if the US keeps pressing. MOFCOM also cast some down on Wednesday's suggestions that a US delegation was to head to Beijing, perhaps as early as next week, saying they had no such information. MOFOC also said that it was not true that President Trump and Xi must meet in order to resolve the trade war.

* USMCA/EUROPEAN TRADE: US Commerce Secretary Ross stated that talks continue with Mexico and Canada on metals tariffs. Ross also said that Trump will decide if auto tariffs talks will continue beyond May, intimating that the decision to delay the imposition of auto tariffs on European vehicles was still to be decided. German Economy Minister Altmaier said later in the session that the EU and the US are expected to begin talks on the cutting of tariffs in weeks

* FED: Governor Brainard (Voter, Dove) said the employment/inflation relationship has "broken down", and weak inflation poses risks that households and businesses could set expectations in a way that makes it harder for the Fed to reach its inflation goal. She stated that the low unemployment is helping the workers at the margin of the labour market, but low interest rates pose risks to financial markets, and that countercyclical capital buffers for banks could allow for a continuation of low rates whilst controlling financial market risks. Fed's Kashkari (Non-Voter, Dove) reiterated familiar dovish arguments that monetary policy has been too tight during the recovery, which has lead to a slower-than-necessary recovery; current low inflation expectations have limited the Fed's ability to respond in the next downturn. He adds that wages are rising but not so fast as to believe that inflation would surge.

* BOC: BOC said overall risk to the nation's financial system has risen slightly since June 2018 amid slowdown in economic growth, oil slump and increased risk-taking in global markets. BoC's Poloz said the risk of a sharp increase in long-term interest rates from increased global risk premiums is moderate, but increasing; he was closely monitoring the the risk of stricter mortgage guidelines shifting consumers towards private lenders. Poloz argued that the fall in global bond yields this year has lowered mortgage rates in Canada, so household borrowing is likely to pick up again, and the BOC is not expecting the household slowdown to be so sharp in Q4. On trade, the MPR noted that the US/China trade war escalation remains a primary risk, and that is still the case currently. BOC's Wilkins said the fragility of corporate debt funding is not a stability issue for the wider financial sector.

* ECB: ECB's Visco said monetary policy can rely on a wide range of tools to support an economy, and the ECB stands ready to fulfil its mandate if necessary; Visco also said it would be a mistake to believe that monetary policy would be disarmed if the Euro Area falls into a recession which led to deflation. ECB's Weidmann blames companies’ savings for driving current account imbalance.

* BREXIT: UK PM May met with the 1922 Committee if backbench MPs, and Committee chair Brady stated that the two agreed to meet following the second reading of the Withdrawal Agreement Bill (which is scheduled to be voted on in the week of the 3rd June) to agree a timetable for the election of a new leader of the Conservative Party; the intention is to have a new leader in place for the Conservative Party conference on 29 September. As it stands, the WAB is still likely to fail, and therefore, attention is shifting on who will be leading the party. Bookies have former foreign minister Boris Johnson leading the race (he today openly said he would be running for the role), followed by former Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab, and former Health Minister Michael Gove (all Brexiteers).

* US MAY PHILLY FED: The Philly Fed stole the thunder of the pre-market US data, putting in an upside surprise beat. Pantheon said the beat was welcome, and reflected the upturn of China PMIs of late. Like the Empire State survey, though, the details are weaker than the headline sentiment index, but were not uniformly at odds with the headline. "Moreover, comparing the Philly sub indexes to the headline ISM national manufacturing index tells the same story as the Empire State, namely, that the drop in the ISM index in April likely will reverse in May." Pantheon says that while it can be said that the industrial economy is weak, it is probably no longer weakening. "The re-escalation of the trade war is a wild card, but China's stimulus means that the global manufacturing story is beginning to turn around," the consultancy wrote, "the sector accounts for only 9% of US jobs and 12% of GDP, but it has a disproportionate impact on markets' perceptions of the state of the economy, so even a modest upturn would be a significant development."

* US APRIL HOUSING STARTS: Also put in an upside beat, rising to 1.235mln, with decent internals (including sing family starts); building permits also beat with the rise in multi-family permits more than offsetting declines in single-family permits. The pace of new residential construction has picked up alongside improving buying conditions, however starts remain below last year’s level, Wells Fargo said.

* US WEEKLY INITIAL JOBLESS CLAIMS: Printed 212k vs 228k prior, undershooting the consensus 220k. The data snapped a run of three consecutive higher readings, and analysts said claims were reverting back to the trend rate.

* GEOPOLITICAL: US President Trump reiterated today that he hopes the US does not go to war with Iran, previous reports suggest there was opposing view within the administration with some of the hawks pushing for increased US presence in the region. The stance was later confirmed by the NYT who reported Trump telling Acting Defense Secretary Shanahan in the Situation Room that he does not want to go to war with Iran. “The risks of a Middle East military confrontation are rising sharply amid twin attacks on energy assets in the Gulf and the US decision to order an evacuation of non-essential personnel from the US Embassy in Baghdad and consulate in Erbil,” RBC’s analysts summarised recent events. A fresh attack from the Saudi-led coalition on the Yemeni capital of Sanaa did not do anything to reduce these risks.

* BANXICO: The Mexican central bank unanimously left rates at 8.25%, as expected, citing inflation edging higher in recent months while the economy is stuttering. There were no revisions to its balance of risks to growth and inflation (inflation risks skewed to the upside in the environment of high uncertainty – risks identified again: MXN, rise of minimum wage, inflation expectations) and is a key reminder to markets that they should be cautious about pricing in rate cuts, Pantheon said. Meanwhile, on Growth, risks are to the downside, and the policymakers added that the outlook has become more uncertain. The Board said it will maintain a prudent monetary policy stance and will pay attention to exchange rate pass-through, Fed policy, and the output gap, as usual. “Overall, we still think that Banxico will keep interest rates on hold over the coming meetings as inflation will remain too high for comfort,” Pantheon says, “But policymakers will start to lay the ground for rate cuts in Q4, as the disinflation trend will resume.” The consultancy notes that demand-related inflation pressures are very limited, the economy weakened in Q1 and the MXN has remained under control, despite many domestic and external threats. “All these factors, coupled with a dovish Fed, will allow Banxico to cut rates,” Pantheon writes, “We assume favourable external conditions, including USMCA ratification and market-friendly domestic policy stance from AMLO.”

* WTI (M9) SETTLES $0.85 HIGHER AT $62.87/BBL, BRENT (N9) SETTLES $0.85 HIGHER AT $72.62/BBL. The crude complex continued to rally on Thursday, catching a tailwind again from geopolitical risk and growing risk appetite. As the US session kicked off, equity markets did too, rising smoothly from the equity open, this sentiment helped push cyclical/risk assets higher such as oil, whilst pushing Treasury yields higher. Bulls are also still benefitting from tensions in the Middle East, where the market is pricing a risk premium over supply concerns. Analysts at PVM noted, “Earlier this morning, a Saudi-led coalition launched air strikes on the Yemeni capital city of Sanaa and is spurring a bout of fresh buying.” Market participants will be paying close attention to see if the dispute with Iran can be settled (or somewhat diminished) via diplomacy, rather than conflict, which would ease concerns. One of which is the risk of Iran halting shipping through the Strait of Hormuz, however analysts at RBC take the view, “While the presence of the US Fifth Fleet in Bahrain means Iran is highly unlikely to close Straits of Hormuz, Iran does have the ability to stage one-off attacks on vessels and leverage both its proxies and asymmetric capabilities.” Looking ahead to this weekend’s JMMC meeting, Iraq oil minister Alluaibi said oil markets and current prices are stable, with no acute volatility; adding that the weekend's JMMC meeting will assess the commitment of OPEC/OPEC+ to production cuts, saying it's too early to predict OPEC decision; if the meeting reveals an eagerness to break away from the committed cuts, this could give way to downside for the market.

* S&P 500 0.9% AT 2876, NASDAQ-100 1% AT 7580, DOW JONES 0.8% AT 25863, SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary 1%, Consumer Staples  0.8%, Energy  0.4%, Financials  1.1%, Health Care  0.8%, Industrials  0.9%, Information Technology  1%, Materials  1.3%, Telecommunication Services  1%, Utilities  0.6%

* STOCK SPECFICS: The Trump administration’s decision to ban US telecommunications companies from using foreign equipment that would pose a threat to national security weighed heavily on a number of tech names with close ties to Chinese technology companies such as Huawei. Qualcom (QCOM), Xilinx (XLNX), Skyworks Solutions (SWKS), Qorvo (QRVO), Micron Technologies (MU), Analog Devices (ADI) and IPG Photonics Corp (IPGP) all finished firmly in the red. Cisco Systems (CSCO), however, shrugged off US/China trade related concerns, moving higher premarket after posting strong earnings; the chipmaker beating expectations on both top and bottom lines whilst revising Q4 guidance higher, a revision which the co said does take into account the impact of tariffs. Walmart (WMT) also moved higher after posting strong earnings. These strong earnings, in addition to strong housing data, helped propel Wall Street to a third consecutive day of gains, in which large tech names were some of the key beneficiaries. Microsoft (MSFT), Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL) and PayPal (PYPL) all moved higher. Amazon (AMZN) also moved higher, with the share price finding additional support form news the tech giant would introduce a new model of its Fire device aimed at children. Banking names including, JP Morgan Chase (JPM) and Citigroup (C), where unfazed after the EU issued fines to multiple firms in relation to involvement in spot foreign exchange cartels. Tesla (TSLA) shares were under pressure after the electric automaker announced it will update its battery software following the spontaneous combustion of another of its Model S vehicles, whilst also facing news that Asset Manager T. Rowe Price had been selling its shares. Healthcare, Pharma and Biotech names also participated in the wider rally, with the exception of Nektar Therapeutics (NKTR), who sunk on a reduction in Sabby Managements 13-F filing. Boeing (BA) caught a bid later in the session on the back of it announcing it had completed a 737 MAX software update.

 

* US T-NOTE FUTURES SETTLE 8 TICKS LOWER AT 124-13+. At settlement, the curve had bear-flattened, though in early trade, there was a bid in the complex after news that Trump was going to take action on Huawei. The tough talk out of China’s MOFCOM also gave support to the complex in the European morning. However, after the European cash open, Treasury yields began to rise, and were booted higher further after a decent slate of US data. After that data, the drift has generally been horizontal.

* BANXICO: The Mexican central bank unanimously left rates at 8.25%, as expected, citing inflation edging higher in recent months while the economy is stuttering. There were no revisions to its balance of risks to growth and inflation (inflation risks skewed to the upside in the environment of high uncertainty – risks identified again: MXN, rise of minimum wage, inflation expectations) and is a key reminder to markets that they should be cautious about pricing in rate cuts, Pantheon said. Meanwhile, on Growth, risks are to the downside, and the policymakers added that the outlook has become more uncertain. The Board said it will maintain a prudent monetary policy stance and will pay attention to exchange rate pass-through, Fed policy, and the output gap, as usual. “Overall, we still think that Banxico will keep interest rates on hold over the coming meetings as inflation will remain too high for comfort,” Pantheon says, “But policymakers will start to lay the ground for rate cuts in Q4, as the disinflation trend will resume.” The consultancy notes that demand-related inflation pressures are very limited, the economy weakened in Q1 and the MXN has remained under control, despite many domestic and external threats. “All these factors, coupled with a dovish Fed, will allow Banxico to cut rates,” Pantheon writes, “We assume favourable external conditions, including USMCA ratification and market-friendly domestic policy stance from AMLO.”

* FX WRAP: A more constructive risk tone has seen havens on the defensive, with JPY (flirts with 110.00), CHF (above 1.01 vs the USD), XAU (breaks through 1292 to the downside) all off, while Treasury yields are higher, though the curve has bear-flattened. Ultimately, the USD is consolidating near the top-end of its weekly range (around 97.85) after a solid Philly Fed report added to the optimism following Wednesday's upbeat Empire State survey, while housing data also supported the Buck. The EUR was taking its cue more from US/German yield spreads widening, rather than the narrowing of the Bund/BTP spread, and trades near lows around 1.1170 heading into APAC trade. The AUD is flat as US traders got to their desks, but is near LOD heading into Asia trade (sub 0.69) after overnight jobs data bolstered the case for looser RBA policy. EMFX also does not appear to be participating in the better risk sentiment, while some idiosyncratic factors are also weighing (particularly for the BRL), although the RUB is faring better as crude prices are up (NOK also firmer). The MXN weakened after Banxico rate decision. GBP remains a function of political headlines, and with PM May heading towards the exit, Brexiteers lead the race to become new leader, and GBP trades sub-1.28. CNH rose to highs in the latter part of US trade (HOD was above 6.93), perhaps adding some caution to risk sentiment.

* AUD: The Aussie fell after the jobless rate ticked up. The jobs data showed better than expected headline at +28k, with the Y/Y rate of job growth rising to the best since June 2018 at 2.6%. However, having been stable at 5.0% for several months, the unemployment rate ticked up to 5.2%, and underutilisation jumped to 13.7% from 13.0% (highest since June 2018), though participation also rose back to an equal record high at 65.8%. UBS said that overall, the labour market is worse than the RBA's repeated view that it "remains strong"; while jobs growth remains solid, unemployment is now trending up, and the broader underutilisation rate (measuring spare capacity) has increased by even more, clearly meeting the RBA's key 'scenario' to cut rates, the bank believes.

* JPY: The Japanese government is mulling downgrading its assessment of the economy next week, Reuters reported, as the US/China trade war exacts its toll on Japanese exports and factory output, according to a government source; the move might fuel speculation that Japan may delay a planned hike in its sales tax for the third time (planned for October). Any decision to delay the tax would likely need to e made before Upper House elections in the summer. The BOJ's next Tankan survey (released 1 July) will offer clues as to whether the sales tax hike would likely be delayed again.

* CNY: The PBOC issued 3-month and one-year bills in HK overnight at higher rates than in February. Analysts said that by selling the bills in Hong Kong, rather than the mainland, the PBOC is signalling a tougher stance on yuan control, which could lead to tighter liquidity conditions that could end up buoying the yuan currency.

* BRL: Fitch ratings gave a negative assessment on the state of fiscal reform, weighing on the BRL. The CRA said that the pension reform agenda was positive, however, the congressional division and uncertainty of the timing of passing the reforms is a problem. Fitch also said that pension reforms were not sufficient to stabilise the nation's public debt, and subsequently, trigger any ratings upgrade. Fitch also noted that domestic growth has failed to take off; this message was re-emphasized after a number of desks again cut their 2019 growth forecasts for Brazil. The Brazil central bank chief himself said that the global economic environment was challenging, and that the slowdown in late 2018 had spilled over into 2019, suggesting that the economy contracted in Q1. Campos Neto also said that inflation risks were symmetric, though a high degree of slack could lead to a lower rate path than previously expected.

The Brazil central bank chief himself said that the global economic environment was challenging, and that the slowdown in late 2018 had spilled over into 2019, suggesting that the economy contracted in Q1. Campos Neto also said that inflation risks were symmetric, though a high degree of slack could lead to a lower rate path than previously expected.

analysis_details: The crude complex continued to rally on Thursday, catching a tailwind again from geopolitical risk and growing risk appetite. As the US session kicked off, equity markets did too, rising smoothly from the equity open, this sentiment helped push cyclical/risk assets higher such as oil, whilst pushing Treasury yields higher. Bulls are also still benefitting from tensions in the Middle East, where the market is pricing a risk premium over supply concerns. Analysts at PVM noted, “Earlier this morning, a Saudi-led coalition launched air strikes on the Yemeni capital city of Sanaa and is spurring a bout of fresh buying.” Market participants will be paying close attention to see if the dispute with Iran can be settled (or somewhat diminished) via diplomacy, rather than conflict, which would ease concerns. One of which is the risk of Iran halting shipping through the Strait of Hormuz, however analysts at RBC take the view, “While the presence of the US Fifth Fleet in Bahrain means Iran is highly unlikely to close Straits of Hormuz, Iran does have the ability to stage one-off attacks on vessels and leverage both its proxies and asymmetric capabilities.” Looking ahead to this weekend’s JMMC meeting, Iraq oil minister Alluaibi said oil markets and current prices are stable, with no acute volatility; adding that the weekend's JMMC meeting will assess the commitment of OPEC/OPEC+ to production cuts, saying it's too early to predict OPEC decision; if the meeting reveals an eagerness to break away from the committed cuts, this could give way to downside for the market.

Daily FX Wrap: DXY surpasses with technical resistance after skirting chart support
content:
USD

The Greenback is now broadly firmer vs its major rivals, and another encouraging regional manufacturing survey has helped the Buck rebound further from recent lows after little initial reaction to US housing data beats. Consequently, the index has breached resistance ahead of 98.000 and the May high (98.102) at 97.747 having just held above the 30 DMA earlier, and if the DXY maintains its recovery momentum then the ytd peak (97.330) could be targeted.

GBP/AUD 

The major laggards with independent weights to compound the aforementioned Buck bounce in the form of heightened Brexit angst and pressure on UK PM May to name her departure date, while Aussie jobs data has lifted RBA rate cut prospects for the June policy meeting. Cable has now seriously tested the resolve of bids around the 1.2800 handle and support ahead of the mid-February low (1.2773) when there was little sign of any Valentine’s Day love for the Pound, but Sterling held up better vs the single currency that suffered another Italian-related blow – more on this to come. Meanwhile, a decline in full time workers and uptick in the unemployment rate raised easing expectations for next month, including so called RBA watcher McCrann, with Aud/Usd down below 0.6900 at one stage and heading back that way after a rebound tailed off around 0.6933.

JPY/EUR

Another improvement in overall risk sentiment, as the tide continues to turn has seen the Yen lose safe-haven premium again and retreat from 109.34 to 109.90 vs the Usd, while the Euro lost grip of 1.1200 after Wednesday’s comeback on potentially positive auto tariff news in wake of more and arguably the most aggressive fiscal defiance from Italian Deputy PM Salvini. Eur/Usd recoiled to 1.1173 and closer to mtd lows (1.1135) as he pledged to rip up all EU rules that are butchering his country if his Party performs well at the forthcoming EU elections.

CHF/NZD 

Also on the backfoot against the Usd as the Franc slipped through 1.0100 and Kiwi waned alongside its antipodean peer from just above 0.6580 towards 0.6650 and overnight lows a few pips below.

CAD

Another choppy session for the Loonie, albeit within a 1.3400-50 range vs its US rival as a firmer rebound in oil prices and positive vibes on the USMCA metals tariff front helped the Cad evade bearish impulses from the aforementioned upbeat US macro releases vs decent Canadian manufacturing sales data and latest diplomatic incident between Canada and the US.

EM

The Real and Lira lamented relatively downbeat ratings reviews from Fitch and Moody’s in contrast to the Rand that continued to outperform in wake of the SA election results and awaiting President Ramaphosa’s latest reform plan. Indeed, Usd/Brl rebounded over 4.0000 and Usd/Try reclaimed 6.0000 vs Usd/Zar holding steady within a 14.2650-1315 range.

16 May 2019

  • The Trump administration is to ban US telecommunications companies from using foreign equipment that would pose a threat to national security, particularly Huawei. Companies that may be impacted include Cisco (CSCO), Juniper (JNPR) HP Inc (HPQ), Ciena (CIEN) F5 Networks (FFIV), Nokia (NOK), Broadcom (AVGO), Qualcomm (QCOM), NeoPhotonics (NPTN), T-Mobile US (TMUS), Skyworks (SWKS), and Xilinx (XLNX).

subject: Nomura quants says conditions appear ripe for favourable headlines to spur US equity bottom-fishing
content:
• Nomura says the European auto tariff delay news lifted spirits, seeing SPX climb back to 2850, and "conditions appear ripe for favorable headlines to spur bottom-fishing, so the timing here makes sense to us." However, it believes it is too soon to say that the stock market retrenchment is over and done with, "as the rebound in US and European equities in the week through 17 May could still prove to be merely a post-plunge technical rebound." The bank believes that a verdict on whether the rally is genuine will require confirmation that major hedge funds have returned to buying.
  • Nomura says that CTAs still appear to be inclined to sell the rebound. "The systematic pressure on CTAs to sell to cut losses dissipated somewhat once the S&P 500 broke above the 2,820 line (corresponding to the average cost of their net buying of futures since January), but our simulation suggests that CTAs are unlikely to swing to trend following net buying this week unless the S&P 500 clears 2,910."
  • Meanwhile, Nomura says that global macro HFs have finished collecting the gains on their short positions in US equities, and have neutral market exposure now. "Traditionally, the stance of global macro HFs on whether to buy or sell has been governed to a large extent by the US economic surprise index and, around this time of year, the index has historically tended to not begin improving (indicating a sustained run of positive US economic surprises) until the beginning of June at the earliest," Nomura writes, and from that erspective, it thinks thsat global macro HFs are unlikely to begin building long positions in US equities before May is over.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 16th May 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European indices [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.3%] are volatile, following on from the somewhat mixed performance of their Asian counterparts
  • China’s MOFCOM spokesman stated that they have no information regarding a US visit to Beijing
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Building Permits, Housing Starts, Initial Jobless Claims & Philadelphia Fed Business Index, Canadian Manufacturing Sales, ECB’s de Guindos & Coeure, Fed’s Kashkari & Brainard, BoC’s Poloz & Wilkins
  • Earnings: Applied Materials, Baidu, NVIDIA, Walmart

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were mixed as blue-chip earnings and the US blacklisting of Huawei as well as 70 of its affiliates overshadowed the positive lead from Wall St, where sentiment was underpinned by reports that President Trump plans to delay the decision on tariffs for auto imports by up to 6-months. ASX 200 (+0.7%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.6%) were mixed in which the commodity-related sectors led the intraday recovery in Australia and as a higher Unemployment Rate stoked calls for an RBA rate cut, while Tokyo trade was pressured by disappointing earnings including Japan’s megabanks Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group. Hang Seng (U/C) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.6%) were initially subdued with underperformance seen in tech and telecoms following US President Trump’s national emergency declaration on foreign companies posing threats to US telecommunications, although strength in property names after firmer Chinese House Price data helped reverse the losses. 10yr JGBs were initially supported as they tracked recent upside in T-notes and amid weakness in Tokyo stocks, although gains were capped after the 5-year JGB auction results were relatively inline with the previous albeit with a weaker b/c.

 

US President Trump signed an executive order declaring national emergency to address threats to telecommunication networks from some foreign firms as expected, while the US Commerce Department placed Huawei and 70 affiliates on its trade blacklist which means licences will be required in order for US companies to sell products to Huawei. (Newswires)

US delegation could head to China for trade talks as early as next week. (Axios) However, in the piece, Axios quoted comments from a Senior US Official on Tuesday that a trade deal with China is not close.

 

China's MOFCOM says the nation firmly opposes bullying by the US, adding that China will have to take countermeasures if the US keeps pressing along

- They have no information regarding a US visit to Beijing adds that It is not true that President Trump and Xi must meet in order to resolve the trade war

- Urges the US to cancel the tariffs on Chinese goods as soon as is possible, in order to prevent causing a recession like impact on the world economy

- China's 3 matters of principle must be resolved before any trade deal can be reached with the US; will never make concessions regarding important matters of principle

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8688 (Prev. 6.8649)

Chinese House Prices (Apr) Y/Y 10.7% (Prev. 10.6%). (Newswires)

 

US

China sold USD 20.5bln of US government bonds during March which was the largest amount sold in over 2 years. (FT)

UK/EU

UK PM May is to be warned that she faces the prospect of confidence vote on June 12th if she does not agree to step down before summer, according to reports in the Telegraph. In related news, UK PM May will tell the executive of the 1922 Committee she needs several more weeks to pass key Brexit legislation in meeting tomorrow, according to FT's political correspondent Laura Hughes. (Telegraph/FT)

ITV Political Editor Peston tweeted Labour MP Emily Thornberry said her party will vote against WAB and signalled cross-party talks may collapse as soon as tomorrow, while Conservative MPs Vaizey and Bridgen agree PM May will be out next month. (Newswires/Twitter)

UK PM May spokesman says there will be more official talks with Labour regarding Brexit in the coming days. (Newswires)

ECB's Visco says that monetary policy can rely on a wide range of tools to support an economy, and the ECB stand ready to fulfill its mandate if necessary, it is a mistake to believe that monetary policy would be disarmed if the Euro Area falls into a recessions which leads to deflation. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICAL

US has ordered the suspension of all commercial and cargo flights to and from Venezuela. (Newswires)

US President Trump is reportedly seeking a diplomatic way to resolve tensions with Iran according to reports, while Washington Post stated Trump is not convinced the time is right to attack Iran. (Newswires/Washington Post)

Iran Foreign Minister Zarif said the country remains committed to the Iran nuclear deal and exercise maximum restraint despite US withdrawal from the deal, while he believes US escalation is unacceptable. (Newswires)

Yemen-based Saudi coalition states that the recent drone attacks on Saudi Oil pipelines are considered a 'war crime', according to Al Arabiy. (Newswires)

Saudi Vice Minister of Defense says the attacks by the Houthis vs. Aramco facilities show they are an Iranian "tool"; Tehran orders are acts that threaten current political efforts. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities have been volatile [Eurostoxx 50 +0.3%] following on from a mostly positive lead in Asia. Sectors are mixed with outperformance in material names (amidst rising base metal prices) whilst consumer discretionary lags as EU auto names pare back some of yesterday’s tariff-spurred gains. In terms of individual movers, Thyssenkrupp (+6.5%) shares rose to the top of the DAX after reports that Finland’s Kone (+3.8%) are exploring the viability of a bid for Thyssenkrupp’s EUR 14bln elevator division. Meanwhile, Thomas Cook (-18.4%) shares opened lower by over 20% after posting a Q1 pre-tax loss of EUR 1.465bln which came alongside a warning that “challenging” trading over the peak summer season would impact FY earnings, although the Co. did note that they have received multiple bids for all and parts of the group airline. Finally, Ubisoft (-12.4%) rests at the foot of the Stoxx 600 despite posting record sales figures, after a delay to its open-world game “Skull & Bones” into the next FY.

 

FX

USD - The Dollar is holding above Wednesday’s post-US data lows, but stands narrowly mixed vs G10 counterparts as the US-China trade dispute continues via recriminations over the cause of the derailment in talks that has sparked another round of reciprocal tariffs. However, the DXY is stuck in a narrow band either side of the 97.500 mark that has been pivotal for a while, and very close to the 30 DMA (94.428) between 97.565-438.

 

NZD/EUR/CAD/JPY/AUD/CHF - All marginally firmer vs the Greenback, with the Kiwi outperforming or clawing back more losses than other so be precise from sub-0.6550 levels to circa 0.6580. Meanwhile, the single currency is holding above 1.1200 after reclaiming big figure+ status yesterday on the EU auto tax reprieve, but unable to breach the 30 DMA (1.1222) convincingly amidst increasingly dovish ECB market expectations and another potential clash between Italy and the EU on budget policy intentions. The Loonie has also rebounded from recent lows and a post-Canadian CPI dip to test resistance ahead of 1.3400 with some positive momentum coming from reports that the Canada, Mexico and the US are close to clinching a deal on steel tariffs (Peso paring losses as well as Usd/Mxn eyes 19.0000). Usd/Jpy continues to straddle 109.50 as the Yen retains a safe-haven bid, but also contends with more decent option expiry interest (1.55 bn from 109.15 to 109.25 and 2.2 bn between 109.40-55). Elsewhere, the Aussie has recovered from its latest slump in wake of more weak data on balance (labour report) and a dip through 0.6900 stops with the aid of underlying bids/short covering, and Aud/Usd has now absorbed supply said to be sitting around 0.6910 and above to trade back up around 0.6933. Lastly, funding for a proposed acquisition has been touted as a factor behind recent Franc strength, but Usd/Chf has bounced towards 1.0100 from a few pips above 1.0050 and Eur/Chf has crossed over 1.1300 again.

 

GBP - Brexit and related UK political uncertainty is still haunting Sterling along with other global and geopolitical risk, with Cable retreating a tad further towards 1.2800 and Eur/Gbp inching close to 0.8750 as PM May meets the 1922 group in just under an hour.

 

EM - The Rand is showing a degree of resilience in the face of somewhat negative reviews from Moody’s on SA’s credit outlook with Usd/Zar hovering at the lower end of 14.2650-1525 trading parameters and perhaps being drawn or attracted to an unusually large expiry at the 14.0000 strike (1.365 bn).

 

Australian Employment Change (Apr) 28.4k vs. Exp. 14.0k (Prev. 25.7k). (Newswires) Australian Full Time Employment Change (Apr) -6.3k (Prev. 48.3k) Australian Unemployment Rate (Apr) 5.2% vs. Exp. 5.1% (Prev. 5.0%)

Australian Participation Rate (Apr) 65.8% vs. Exp. 65.7% (Prev. 65.7%)

 

South Korea President Moon says fiscal policy needs to be more actives to raise jobs and urges parliament for speedy approval of additional budget. (Newswires)

FIXED INCOME

The latest advance in debt futures and decline in cash yields has stalled even though remarks from China show little sign of easing in trade tensions with the US, and knowledge about a meeting in Beijing to try and restore relations. 10 year benchmarks have all eased back from best levels towards intraday lows after Bunds faded at 167.27, Gilts at 129.03 and US Treasuries at 124-27, with the notable exception of Spanish Bonos that saw decent buying interest on their way up to a 153.31 high and have only drifted back a few ticks since. Ahead, another potential Brexit game-changer as UK PM May meets the 1922 mob at 11.30BST and then a raft of US data before more global Central Bank speakers.

 

COMMODITIES

A positive session thus far for WTI (+0.7%) and Brent (+0.5%) futures as tensions in the Middle East drift back into focus. The former remains above USD 62.00/bbl and in close proximity to USD 62.50/bbl whilst its Brent counterpart floats comfortably above the USD 72.00/bbl mark. On the Iranian front, ship tracking data showed that a tanker carrying Iranian oil (in violation with US sanctions) has unloaded its cargo of almost 130k tonnes of oil near Zhousan, in China. Iran will remain a focus as the JMMC convene this weekend in Jeddah, with ministers expected to discuss whether the supply gap from Iranian sanctions will need to be filled, and hence whether the output curb deal will need to be extended until the end of the year.  In terms of technicals, analysts at PVM highlight resistance at 63.09 (21 DMA) in WTI and 72.60 in Brent (short-term DMA) which they believe will be tested today given the optimism emanating from Trump’s decision to delay EU auto tariffs, progress regarding the Canadian and Mexican aluminium and steel tariffs and concerns of supply disruptions from Middle Eastern tensions. Looking at metals, gold remains choppy below the 1300/oz level and flirts with its 100 DMA at 1296.82 ahead of its 50 DMA (1291.69). Elsewhere, copper prices are poised to notch a third day of gains amid a weakening buck and optimism surrounding Trump’s auto tariff delays with the red metal now back above 2.75/lb ahead of its 200 DMA at 2.7604.

Iraq oil Ministry reportedly denied that ExonnMobil workers are to evacuate from work sites in Iraqi territory. (Newswires)

content: Gilts gapped up 21 ticks from the get-go, and following an early wobble akin to the price action in Bunds, recovery gains subsequently doubled with the 10 year bond reaching 129.01 before topping out again. Note, yesterday’s Liffe high was 129.05 and forms the nearest if not first line of resistance as core debt regroups and bounces off Wednesday’s lows prompted by reports of a delay on US auto tariffs, and the Short Sterling strip is also back on the front foot (Jun19 contract aside) ahead of another potentially defining moment for UK PM May and perhaps in the context of the whole Brexit saga.

subject: China's MOFCOM says the nation firmly opposes bullying by the US, adding that China will have to take countermeasures if the US keeps pressing along
content:
• They have no information regarding a US visit to Beijing
  • It is not true that President Trump and Xi must meet in order to resolve the trade war
  • Urges the US to cancel the tariffs on Chinese goods as soon as is possible, in order to prevent causing a recession like impact on the world economy
  • Adds that China's 3 matters of principle must be resolved before any trade deal can be reached with the US
  • China will never make concessions regarding important matters of principle
analysis_details:
Regarding the 3 matters of principle:

1. China believes that all punitive tariffs must be cancelled if an agreement is reached.

2. Last year US President Trump and Chinese President Xi agreed to a preliminary figure for the purchase of US good following the declaration of a trade truce in Argentina. Following this, clarification is needed around the figure; as both sides now have different views, with China believing this a serious thing which cannot easily be altered.

3. Text around the agreement must be balanced between the US and China, as both countries need their own dignity.

subject: Bunds: back above 167.00 after auto-driven reversal
content: The 10 year German benchmark looks to be building a platform for another upside foray after Wednesday’s abrupt fall from grace on reports that US President Trump could extend the deadline on EU auto tariffs by up to 6 months from the original May 18 due date. Indeed, after a relatively modest mark up to 167.06 and fleeting dip to 167.04, Bunds have been grinding higher to 167.23 compared to yesterday’s 166.94 Eurex close and an earlier intraday pinnacle of 167.43 that surpassed the previous contract high by some distance. Ahead, Italian data, Eurozone trade, ECB speak via de Guindos, Praet and Coeure, plus supply from France.

RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 16th May 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian indices were mixed as the auto-driven positivity from Wall St. was countered by the blacklisting of Huawei and disappointing regional earnings
  • UK PM May is to face the 1922 committee today, with the committee to hold a meeting immediately after; cross-party talks with Labour remain on the verge of collapsing
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Building Permits, Housing Starts, Initial Jobless Claims & Philadelphia Fed Business Index, Canadian Manufacturing Sales, ECB’s Praet, de Guindos & Coeure, Fed’s Kashkari & Brainard, BoC’s Poloz & Wilkins
  • Earnings: Applied Materials, Baidu, NVIDIA, Walmart, Generali

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were mixed as blue-chip earnings and the US blacklisting of Huawei as well as 70 of its affiliates overshadowed the positive lead from Wall St, where sentiment was underpinned by reports that President Trump plans to delay the decision on tariffs for auto imports by up to 6-months. ASX 200 (+0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.7%) were mixed in which the commodity-related sectors led the intraday recovery in Australia and as a higher Unemployment Rate stoked calls for an RBA rate cut, while Tokyo trade was pressured by disappointing earnings including Japan’s megabanks Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group. Hang Seng (+0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.3%) were initially subdued with underperformance seen in tech and telecoms following US President Trump’s national emergency declaration on foreign companies posing threats to US telecommunications, although strength in property names after firmer Chinese House Price data helped reverse the losses. 10yr JGBs were initially supported as they tracked recent upside in T-notes and amid weakness in Tokyo stocks, although gains were capped after the 5-year JGB auction results were relatively inline with the previous albeit with a weaker b/c.

 

US President Trump signed an executive order declaring national emergency to address threats to telecommunication networks from some foreign firms as expected, while the US Commerce Department placed Huawei and 70 affiliates on its trade blacklist which means licences will be required in order for US companies to sell products to Huawei. (Newswires)

US delegation could head to China for trade talks as early as next week. (Axios) However, in the piece, Axios quoted comments from a Senior US Official on Tuesday that a trade deal with China is not close.

 

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net neutral daily position. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8688 (Prev. 6.8649)

 

Chinese House Prices (Apr) Y/Y 10.7% (Prev. 10.6%). (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK PM May is to be warned that she faces the prospect of confidence vote on June 12th if she does not agree to step down before summer, according to reports in the Telegraph. In related news, UK PM May will tell the executive of the 1922 Committee she needs several more weeks to pass key Brexit legislation in meeting tomorrow, according to FT's political correspondent Laura Hughes. (Telegraph/FT)

UK Labour spokesperson said the Labour will vote against the Withdrawal Bill and not abstain if it does not meet their conditions. Furthermore, ITV Political Editor Peston tweeted Labour MP Emily Thornberry said her party will vote against WAB and signalled cross-party talks may collapse as soon as tomorrow, while Conservative MPs Vaizey and Bridgen agree PM May will be out next month. (Newswires/Twitter)

ECB's Praet said persistency of uncertainties is undermining confidence and creating major risks to global economies. (Newswires)

FX

 

DXY remained subdued around the 97.50 level following the prior day’s losses which was largely due to the fallout from a stronger EUR/USD on the reports of President Trump’s auto tariff delay. GBP/USD languished firmly below the 1.2900 handle and at 3-month lows ahead of PM May’s day of reckoning with the 1922 Committee in which some expect her to be gone by next month, while some also anticipate cross-party talks could collapse as early as today. USD/JPY was choppy around 109.50 with price action contained by several nearby large option expiries for today’s New York cut, while antipodeans softened and AUD/USD briefly declined to its lowest level since the start of January after mixed jobs data in which Employment Change topped estimates but was solely fuelled by Part-Time jobs, and the Unemployment Rate increased to 5.2% from a prior revised 5.1% which added to the case for future RBA rate cuts. Furthermore, several large banking names including Citi, Westpac and Morgan Stanley all expect RBA rate cuts in August and November, while SocGen recommended to fade rallies in AUD/USD with a target of 0.6800.

 

Australian Employment Change (Apr) 28.4k vs. Exp. 14.0k (Prev. 25.7k). (Newswires) Australian Full Time Employment Change (Apr) -6.3k (Prev. 48.3k) Australian Unemployment Rate (Apr) 5.2% vs. Exp. 5.1% (Prev. 5.0%)

Australian Participation Rate (Apr) 65.8% vs. Exp. 65.7% (Prev. 65.7%)

 

COMMODITIES

 

Commodities were mixed in which oil prices held on to the gains during the US session where sentiment was lifted by news of Trump plans to delay the auto tariff decision by 6-months. This lifted WTI crude futures above the USD 62.00/bbl level, while a surprise build in DoE crude inventories did little to dent the gains as they were less than the prior day’s API build. Elsewhere, gold prices were steady despite the softer greenback although the precious metals remained in close proximity for another attempt on the psychological USD 1300/oz level, while copper was indecisive amid the varied overnight risk tone.

GEOPOLITICS 

US has ordered the suspension of all commercial and cargo flights to and from Venezuela. (Newswires)

US President Trump is reportedly seeking a diplomatic way to resolve tensions with Iran according to reports, while Washington Post stated Trump is not convinced the time is right to attack Iran. (Newswires/Washington Post)

Iran Foreign Minister Zarif said the country remains committed to the Iran nuclear deal and exercise maximum restraint despite US withdrawal from the deal, while he believes US escalation is unacceptable. However, there were earlier comments by Iran’s Revolutionary Guard Commander who said we are on the cusp of a full-scale confrontation with the enemy and that the Islamic Republic is at its most decisive moment in history due to enemy pressure. (Newswires)

UAE said it is committed to peace as well as de-escalation and wants to emphasise caution. Furthermore, it added there are serious problems including Iran's behaviour although it has not concluded investigation on oil tanker attacks. (Newswires) 

US

Trade sentiment was again the driving factor for Treasury price moves on Wednesday. In early trade, however, the T-Note was again taking its cue from EGB's, where the Bund/BTP spread widened as participants digested comments from the Italian Deputy PM Salvini, who stated that EU deficit rules can be breached if measures would support growth (Setting up another conflict with both his coalition partners, as well as the EU). But since US traders got to their desks, the T-Note essentially became more horizontal (continuing to rise until news broke that Trump had pushed-back the decision on imposing auto tariffs on imports of EU vehicles, but then seeing modest negative ticks). At settlement, major curve spreads were a touch wider/unchanged. US T-notes (M9) futures settled 11 ticks higher at 124-21+.

Fed's Barkin (Non-Voter, Hawk) said it makes sense for the Fed to remain patient on rates and that inflation weakness is likely transitory. Barkin added there is not a strong case to move rates higher with inflation under control, nor is there a strong case to move rates lower when growth remains healthy. (Newswires)

China sold USD 20.5bln of US government bonds during March which was the largest amount sold in over 2 years. (FT)

Mexico Deputy Foreign Minister Seade said they are nearing a deal with US to lift steel tariffs. (Newswires)
